Award.AwardTitle: NCLSAMP Bridge to The Doctorate Fellowship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Graduate studies are often funded by university supported teaching assistantships, research assistantships, fellowships and federal student aid programs. Traditionally, funding for master?s level graduate education has been limited, and students often have to fund their own education; making a full-time commitment to academics and research cost prohibitive. North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NCA&T), a historically black college and land-grant university, is one of four Ph.D. granting institutions within the NCLSAMP Alliance, and leads the University of North Carolina (UNC) System in the production of STEM degrees (Evans, 2012). The overall goal of the BD Fellowship Program at NCA&T is to increase the number of science and engineering majors who pursue PhDs in STEM fields. Specific objectives are to: 1) Recruit a cadre of STEM graduate students who have the potential for academic success, and the desire to pursue a STEM PhD.; 2) Provide academic development workshops, financial support, and experiences to promote the retention of participants; and 3) Assist students in their transition to graduate studies and ultimately the PhD.
Utilizing strategic initiatives aligned with the North Carolina A&T Strategic Plan, ?Preeminence 2020?, the Bridge to the Doctorate Fellowship Program at NCA&T will produce 12 highly competitive graduate students who have experience in the interdisciplinary applications of science and mathematics in scholarship and research relevant to 21st century STEM workforce development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Fellowship Program at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T) was developed to facilitate the recruitment and retention of STEM graduate students into the university and to assist in their successful transition into Master's and PhD programs.  Project goals, as articulated in the funded proposal, were to: recruit a cadre of STEM graduate students who have potential for academic success and a desire to pursue a STEM PhD; retain BD Fellows by providing professional development workshops, financial support and experiences to promote successful matriculation; and assist students in making the transition to graduate studies and ultimately to PhD programs. Specifically, the Bridge to the Doctorate sought to retain 100% of program participants in North Carolina A&T Master's level STEM majors and provide professional development and student support activities to facilitate student transition to North Carolina Agricultural &Technical State University graduate studies and PhD programs.

Twelve fellows enrolled in the Bridge to the Doctorate Program at North Carolina A&T State University. The cohort was comprised of 2 males and 10 females. Eleven fellows were identified as African American and one (female) identified as Hispanic. Fellows were enrolled in two year thesis based Master’s programs in Applied Mathematics (2), Biology (7), Chemistry (1) and Industrial and Systems Engineering (2).  Fellows participated in a BD Orientation program which welcomed them to NCA&T and provided an overview of both the BD program and graduate studies at NCA&T.  Workshops to ease the transition to graduate study and assist in the application to PhD programs were offered throughout the program and included the following topics: “Managing the Graduate School Experience”, “GRE Prep”, “Graduate Research Fellowship Application Training”, “Thesis and Dissertation Writing Workshop”, “Work Life Balance and Stress Management”. Students also participated in workshops and trainings offered by their respective departments and the Graduate School.

To date, nine BD Fellows have earned Master’s degrees.  The average GPA at graduation was 3.84, and it should be noted that attrition was not for academic reasons. Of the three students who have not completed their respective graduate programs, one informed BD staff that he would not pursue a PhD and withdrew from the program, another returned home at the beginning of his final semester to take care of family matters, but has indicated his intention to complete his Master’s and pursue a PhD in Chemistry,  and the final did not return after the Fall 2016 semester and has not responded to BD staff request for updates on her status. Of the nine students who earned Master’s degrees four, all female, are currently enrolled in PhD programs. They are enrolled at Johns Hopkins University (Pharmacology & Molecular Science) North Carolina State University (Epidemiology/Population Medicine) Purdue University (Engineering Education) and University of North Carolina at Greensboro (Nanoscience). The remaining graduates are employed in STEM industries which call on them to utilize the expertise gained as Master’s students. Two have expressed the desire to return to academia and earn a PhD. 

The Bridge to the Doctorate  at North Carolina A&T State University contributes to achieving societal goals, as articulated by the National Science Foundation, through  intellectual merit and broader impact. Specifically, BD fellows have engaged in cutting edge research in the fields of Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics and Engineering and have shared research finding at regional and national professional conferences. As PhD students, they continue to contribute to the generation of new knowledge in Molecular Biology, Nanoscience, Epidemiology and Engineering Education; areas that are critical to the national interest.  Additionally, as members of groups historically underrepresented in STEM PhD programs, NC-LSAMP BD fellows will be actively engaged in expanding the frontiers of science and engineering as they bring to the academic and research enterprise the potential for paradigmatic shifts based upon differing world views, priorities and epistemologies. They will also continue to serve as role models and mentors for younger students, as they did in their tenure as BD fellows.  Their presence in STEM PhD programs communicates to other URM students; undergraduate and younger, that STEM careers in the Sciences and Engineering are obtainable and worth pursuing.
